sen.j: 智光（ちこう、和銅2年（709年）? － 宝亀11年（780年）?）は、奈良時代の三論宗の僧。
sen.e: Ko CHI (709? - 780?) was a Buddhist priest of the Sanron sect during the Nara period.

Chiko (circa 709 - circa 780) was a Buddhist priest of the Sanron Sect (Madhyamika school founded originally by Nagarjuna, which was brought in from China in 625 by Ekwan and was headquartered in Horyu-ji Temple in Nara, the sect belonging to the Provisional Mahayana school), who lived in the Nara period.
sen.cmt: 人名・形式・表現を修正しました
sen.e: Chiko (circa 709 - circa 780) was a Buddhist priest of the Sanron Sect (Madhyamika school founded originally by Nagarjuna, which was brought in from China in 625 by Ekwan and was headquartered in Horyu-ji Temple in Nara, the sect belonging to the Provisional Mahayana school), who lived in the Nara period.

sen.j: 俗性は鋤田連（すきたのむらじ）。
sen.e: His lay-name was SUKITA no Miraji.
His secular surname was Sukita no muraji.
sen.cmt: 形式・表現を修正しました
sen.e: His secular surname was Sukita no muraji.
Born in Asukabe county in Kawachi Province
He was born in Asukabe no kori (or Asukabe-gun) County in Kawachi Province.
sen.cmt: 用語・形式を修正しました
sen.e: He was born in Asukabe no kori (or Asukabe-gun) County in Kawachi Province.

sen.j: 頼光とともに元興寺の智蔵に師事して三論を学び、聖教を周覧して「般若心経述義」「浄名玄論略述」など多くの書物を著した。
sen.e: Together with Ko RAI he studied Sanron sect Buddhism under So CHI at Gango-ji temple and wrote numerous overviews of Confucianism including: `Hannya-shingyo Jutsugi` and 'Jomyogenron-ryakujutsu' etc.

Together with Raiko he studied Sanron, or Three Shastras (Treatises), under Chizo at Gango-ji Temple, looked around for shogyo (Buddhist sutras) and left numerous writings including "Hannya-shingyo Jutsugi" (literally, Interpretation Learning of Heart Sutra) and "Jomyogenron-ryakujutsu" (literally, A Brief Sketch of the Commentary on the Vimalakirti Nirdesa Sutra).
sen.cmt: 人名・用語・表現を修正しました。「浄名玄論」英訳参考：http://www.emuseum.jp/detail/101075/000/000?mode=simple&d_lang=en&s_lang=en&word=Commentary+on+the+Vimalakirti+Sutra&class=&title=&c_e=&region=&era=&century=&cptype=&owner=&pos=1&num=1
sen.e: Together with Raiko he studied Sanron, or Three Shastras (Treatises), under Chizo at Gango-ji Temple, looked around for shogyo (Buddhist sutras) and left numerous writings including "Hannya-shingyo Jutsugi" (literally, Interpretation Learning of Heart Sutra) and "Jomyogenron-ryakujutsu" (literally, A Brief Sketch of the Commentary on the Vimalakirti Nirdesa Sutra).

sen.j: 「日本現報善悪霊異記」によると、行基が大僧正に任じられたのを妬んで行基を誹謗したため、病を得て没して地獄に落ちたが、懺悔して蘇り行基に帰依したという。
sen.e: According to `Nihon Ryouiki` (set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century) he was jealous of the priest Gyoki serving as high priest so, to slander Gyoki he said that Gyoki had fallen ill died and descended to hell however, had repented and been resurrected in the form of Gyoki.

According to "Nihon genho zenaku ryoiki" (a set of three books of Buddhist stories written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually referred to as the "Nihon Ryoiki"), Chiko was jealous of Gyoki appointed as daisojo (head priest of a Buddhist sect) and slandered him, which supposedly caused Chiko to die of illness and descend to hell, but repentance led him to resurrection, and thus resurrected Chiko relied on Gyoki.
sen.cmt: 誤解釈につき、全体を再訳出しました
sen.e: According to "Nihon genho zenaku ryoiki" (a set of three books of Buddhist stories written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually referred to as the "Nihon Ryoiki"), Chiko was jealous of Gyoki appointed as daisojo (head priest of a Buddhist sect) and slandered him, which supposedly caused Chiko to die of illness and descend to hell, but repentance led him to resurrection, and thus resurrected Chiko relied on Gyoki.

sen.j: また、学友の頼光が没した後、頼光が智光の夢に現れ阿弥陀浄土に往生を遂げているのを見て、画工に描かせたのが、現在奈良元興寺極楽坊の残る「智光曼荼羅」と呼ばれる変相図である。
sen.e: Also, after his schoolmate Ko RAI died, Ko RAI appeared in one of Ko CHI`s dreams where he was seen living in paradise whereupon he had a picture drawn of the scene however, what remains to the present day at Gango-ji temple in Nara is a work called `Ko CHI`s enlightenment`.

Also, after his schoolmate Raiko died, Raiko appeared in one of Chiko's dreams where he was seen living in the Amida jodo (Pure Land of Amida), whereupon he had a picture drawn of the scene by a painter, which remains to the present day at Gokuraku-bo of Gango-ji Temple in Nara as a henso-zu (picture describing Buddhist Heaven and Pure Land) called "Chiko Mandala."
sen.cmt: 誤解釈箇所を再訳出し、表現・用語を修正しました
sen.e: Also, after his schoolmate Raiko died, Raiko appeared in one of Chiko's dreams where he was seen living in the Amida jodo (Pure Land of Amida), whereupon he had a picture drawn of the scene by a painter, which remains to the present day at Gokuraku-bo of Gango-ji Temple in Nara as a henso-zu (picture describing Buddhist Heaven and Pure Land) called "Chiko Mandala."

sen.j: 以後智光は浄土信仰に徹している。
sen.e: Subsequently, Ko CHI persisted with his Jodo (Pure Land) Buddhism beliefs.
Subsequently, Chiko persisted with his Jodo (Pure Land) faith.
